newsitem.title: PERU: Peru insurer pays Aeroperu $63.5 mln for crash.
newsitem.headline: Peru insurer pays Aeroperu $63.5 mln for crash.

text.p: A Peruvian insurance firm said Monday it has reimbursed Mexican-owned airline Aeroperu $63.5 million for last October's crash of a Boeing 757-200 that killed 70 passengers when it plunged into the Pacific near Lima.

"We have honored the policy signed by the contracting airline Empresa de Transporte Aereo del Peru (Aeroperu) by indemnifying the company and the owners of the body and turbine," Popular y Porvenir said in a statement.
The insurance firm said it indemnified the airline for the loss of the aircraft built by Boeing for $55 million and the turbine built by Pratt & Whitney at a cost of $6.5 million.
Popular y Porvenir also paid $2 million to cover search, rescue and other operations associated with the crash, it said.

The aircraft crashed into the sea Oct. 2 minutes after departing Lima's Jorge Chavez International Airport en route to Santiago, Chile. All those aboard, the majority of whom were Chilean, were killed.
The crash was blamed on human error.
